Several cube skeletons rotated about their main diagonals and fused together.
To minimise overhanging edges, it's been turned so a diagonal is pointing upwards; and a plinth added.

Printed out on a Replicator, ~7cm tall using default ReplicatorG settings (except the platform temperature was increased to 110Â°C). Full support (internal + external) and a raft were used - hours of fun pulling the support out with tweezers and an X-Acto knife. (It will probably print with just external support, but I haven't tried it yet.)

------------------------------- Because of limited space, the cable grooves have been removed. Some other changes have been made. There is no mounting position for Touch pcb.
The desk stand and z axis mount holes are compatible.

NOTE: If you actually print this can you send me a picture of the front side. I wan't to check the screen alignment in relation to the frame. I have printed a really early version where it wasn't aligned.

I made this for my personal use and decided to share it. It is provided as is, with no guarantee that it will fit your display. It should fit the results of the ebay search provided (both the touchscreen and display only variants.

https://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2047675.m570.l1313.TR0.TRC0.H0.X7%27%27+HDMI+HD+1024x600+Touch+Screen+Display+Module+Board+Kit+Set+For+Raspberry+Pi.TRS0&_nkw=7%27%27+HDMI+HD+1024x600+Touch+Screen+Display+Module+Board+Kit+Set+For+Raspberry+Pi&_sacat=0

The design accommodates a few different ways of mounting.

  1. Wall hanger (A 3D printed optional part provided)
  2. Desk stand (A 3D printed optional part provided)\
  3. VESA 75mm mount
  4. Single screw on the bottom side (no guarantees that the plastic could support the weight without breaking.
  5. Multiple holes on the back that provide you with the ability to use your own design for a mount.
  6. A Z-Axis mount (For a personal project of mine to have the RPi on my reprap with a touchscreen)

UPDATES:

1.The front part wasn't able to handle the screw pressure so I had to drill out the holes. Perhaps some cosmetic Hex cup nuts would fix the issue.

  1. A: I increased the length of the screw hole on the front panel. they should hold now.
    B: Also I decreased the size of the hole so the metal inserts shouldn't be required any more.

  2. A: Added a hole next to the buttons for the ir sensor (you might need to bend the sensor slightly)
    B: Moved the main driver board so it better aligns with the LCD flat flex cable.
    C: Added a new screw hole so that that the case closes better.
    D: Reduced the size of the buttons so that they don't misclick if you tighten the case.
    E: Finalised the Z-axis mount. (8mm smooth rod mount)
    F: Converted the Groups to components in the *.skp file so that changes to one of the "views" are automatically transferred to the others.
    G: Modified the Z-axis clamp (8mm rod clamp) so it doesn't interfere with the cable "tie"

  3. Modified the wall hanger for better structural strength.

title: Runcam Split mount for Armattan Chameleon

description.text:
With this mount you can install a Runcam Split FPV camera in the Armattan Chameleon frame instead of a dedicated FPV camera. That way there's no need for a dedicated HD camera, making the whole build lighter and the camera is sufficiently far up front to (almost) not see the props in the HD footage.

The Chameleon's original camera holder is rather complex but doesn't work with the Runcam Split. That's why I replaced most of the original parts with a single component that takes up the camera and mounts to the frame. The uptilt is 30 degrees.

The two holes used for connecting with the frame are intentionally bigger than the M3 screws in the frame (I'm using two pairs of short nylon screws). That way there is a little wiggle space between the screws and the camera mount, hopefully reducing the chance of camera jello.

Caution #1: make sure to use at least one long M3 screw to interconnect both metal halfes, otherwise you're running the risk of bending them in a crash.

Caution #2: make sure to print the camera mount in the correct orientation, that is lying on the side, so that the part looks like a "C" and not like a "U". Although this requires support, the strength of the part is a LOT higher (against forward directed forces, as in a frontal crash).

Printer:

XYZ Davinci

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

40%

description.text:
This is a set of mounts that can be used to attach action cameras (like Runcam 2, Runcam 3, GoPro Session etc.) to the tiedowns of a high wing Cessna (like 150 / 152 / 172 and potentionally others).

I used a M30 screw and bolt to securely fix the mount to the aircraft. The camera is attached to the mount using velcro tape (between camera and camera mount) and velcro straps (around camera and camera mount).

Using the various mounts you can have the camera look straight forward, tilted sideways, straight and tilted backwards.

Caution: make sure to print with the right orientation, that is with the objects lying on their long narrow sides. That way, the strength against bending is a LOT higher.

title: Water Tap Ball Valve Handle Lever Faucet Replacement (For Pill Shape Thread)

description.text:
Replacement Tap handle for Pill shape water / Tap / Ball Valves on the market.

Why you need this:

  • Child safe removable handle. Hide the handle and kids can't turn gas / water on and blow up or flood your house. (Hide it somewhere nearby)
  • Space Saving - Replace the 'long and unbalanced' space hogging lever in Brass ball valves especially if you're short on space in tight spaces under the sink, and you can also remove the handle when not in use to save even more space and store nearby.
  • If you broke a lever / knob while trying to de-rust an old tap, this replacement handle is for you.
  • Better than circular knobs; This gives Way better grip for stubborn stiff taps than a circular knob and uses less plastic to print.
    Scale accordingly to fit any male thread (the Circular- Rectangle, Pill shape type)
    Currently set to 7mm x 10mm as per picture.
    Actual STL part is about 5% larger, which allows a snug fit for easy removal or glue addition as desired. .

There are 2 handle types,

  • one with a screw hole, for screwing in, (currently the screw hole is set to 5mm and works well for screws of any size up to 5mm diameter)
  • one without screw hole, smooth finish (portable or if you're using glue or damaged the screw)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

As desired

Notes:

Use higher infill for tougher stiff taps.

Note: If you're printing this because you broke your tap original handle, then you probably need to open the tap and clean out the inside of the tap too.
Spray paint black or white after printing to protect from UV damage if using outdoors.

author: RISI

description.text:
This is a carriage that works with the Bulldog XL, E3D Hot End and linear bearings in conjunction with lawsy's linear bearing mounts.
This will replace the stacked design with a simple snap into place carriage for the extruder only. All credit goes to lawsy, adrian and 2n2r5 for getting the ball rolling.
Happy Printing

Print it solid with no infill or support on its side at .3mm with a good brim. The support is built in so some clean up is required.
Especially around the nut holders for the belt and the fan area. most of the support will clean up well with a good razor. You will have to drill small holes for the fan screws. The fan duct support needs to be removed to allow air to move towards the hot end. The fan supplied with the Bulldog moves enough air that the fan supplied with the E3D is not needed or recommended as you would have two fans pushing against one another.
The FBCAR.stl is for the forward bearings and prints like an upside down U with the same settings and when complete should just snap into the main carriage. (do this after the rear bearings are on the rear rod and clipped into place). Then just swing the carriage down onto the FBCAR that is clipped onto the forward rod. (even with the right side)
I have added the rear fan assembly which replaces the FBCAR with an integrated G-code controlled fan duct. This is a tight fit but snaps in just like the FBCAR did. You'll have to glue the fan to the duct in my case the fan came with adhesive so it was just peel and stick.
Happy Printing

comments.text: This design is working great!  I had the nut holder on the bottom break away while tightening, so will need to print again and maybe brace it better.  However over all working very well and fits the BulldogXL really well.

description.text:
I designed this organizer to help me to keep my reloading desk from getting as messy and to keep frequently used tools close at hand. It is cost effective for me to reload .308 but that is about the only cartridge, so this is geared around that. It holds simple measuring spoons from Wal-Mart, a couple dummy rounds for .308 and .223, break down cleaning rod, primmer pocket cleaning tool, case deburr tool, nylon and brass bristle brushes, picks and then has a small tray for other odds and ends. The .223 dummy rounds are for those that have AR-15s and keep the dummy rounds for cleaning purposes. If there is any interest, I can upload the step file as well. This organizer may be useful for other organizing purposes as well.

Please note that this is my first contribution to the community. I am a former machine designer and engineer for automotive related automation. Now that I am out of the design game, 3D printing is a way for me to scratch an itch. Hopefully more designs to come, let me know what you think.

Designed in AutoCAD Inventor. Printed on a Monoprice Maker Select.

description.text:
This ancient curiosity spins one way easily, but refuses to spin the other way! Watch it instead rattle and start to spin back the other way!
(Before I realized that the key to getting jaysay's excellent design to work was a gentle sanding, I spent a week designing my own. The original still works better than this one, nevertheless, I thought I'd share.)

To prepare:
  • Print. (I've oriented it at a 45 degree angle to maximize printable space.)
  • Gently sand the bottom of the curved surface especially near the center. It doesn't have to be entirely smooth, just smoother than fresh off the printer.
    • To use:
  • Place on smooth, flat surface curved side down.
  • Flick one end to make it spin.
  • Watch closely. Does it keep spinning?
  • Flick it the other way.
  • Watch closely. How is its movement in this direction different?
  • Observe the shape to figure out why!

CCSS

This is intended to be used in the first part of a lesson on graphing sine and cosine functions. You can find the lesson files and another object used in the lesson here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2423988
Many times students do not make the connection between graphs of sine and cosine and how they are formed from y and x coordinates around the unit circle. This tool is meant to help them get a hands-on feel for how these graphs are formed.

Graphing Sin(x) Using an equally spaced x-axis, mark out pi/6, pi/3, pi/2, 2pi/3, 5pi/6, pi, ... for points placed every pi/6 units around the unit circle. Place the midline of the unit circle on the graph axis, and line up each axis tick-mark with it's corresponding terminal point on the unit circle. This will plot points on a sine curve since you are plotting the y-coordinate of each point as a distance above the axis. Graphing Cos(x) Do the same thing for sin(x), but turn the unit circle sideways so that you are plotting the x-coordinate distance above the x-axis.

title: Davinci Pro 1.0 Bowden tube to hotend fix

description.text:
As I was unhappy with the way Davinci "designed" the entrance of the Bowden tube into the top of the hotend, I designed this to have a friction-free path of the filament within the Bowden tube.

The idea is to move the double pneumatic coupler in the top of the hotend to a full vertical position and slip this thingy over the Bowden tube so it makes a smooth 90 degree curve.

See the attached photo for the general idea. The original design where the double coupler is forded to the side makes the Bowden inside the hotend pinch the filament. Print results have improved considerably using this simple fix.

description.text:
Hi, this is my first attempt at designing something to print. Fed up with paying out for original Nespresso capsules, I started looking into refillable ones. When I searched for filling stations on eBay/Amazon, the prices are way to high for what you get, so I designed this on Freecad (before I found Fusion 360!)

Unfortunately, as I'm only starting out, I can't help with print settings etc. as I printed it on my Flashforge Finder with the easy print screen.

There are four little holes in the base and middle part to allow magnets to be used to hold it down (as can be seen in my photo,) but I found that when using, the parts are tight enough that they stay in place.

I've used my design with Sealpod refillable pods and it works well. I'm hoping to complete further designs for other amounts of pods in the future.

Any questions, please feel free to ask and I'll try my best to answer.

L connector for deck panels

This is a home switch mount for the Y axes on the 3020T CNC Engraver/Router. The micro switch used is labeled CQC 10T85. It has a mounting hole spacing of 9.55mm with 2.43mm hole diameters. The mount and the switch have an interference fit, so the included retainer is not really needed.

title: Handtuchaufhänger für Dusche - Towel rail for shower

description.text:
A quite simple towel holder wich is stable enough to stay for a while.

The old one was bough and didn´t cope with the wet towels.. so a new one had to be aquired. Why not print one.... the hooks and the mounting are printed with PLA with 35% infill. And they really a lot more stable than the old one was. The tube is a simple aluminium pipe from the nearest hardware store. I used a 20 mm one. If you need a bigger or smaller one,.. just modify the holes.. :-)
This is also, why I did enclose the 123d-Design file... just form it to your needs.

Would be great, if you´d upload a photo of your printed one and if you will make a small donation, that would help me immensly to stay online creating other things..... :-)

title: Samsung Charger-mount/shelf
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Uploaded by request

Remixed a model from ToScH
https://www.thingiverse.com/ToScH/about
copied the same License as original

Actually maybe it's not a remix, i never downloaded his file.. however its inspired by a picture of his model so i still think it's a remix :)

This is made to fit the Samsung charger that comes with EU-phones (been the same for my S7 Edge and S8 so i think they all come with the same socket (EU-socket for 230V, Schuko)

Two files one for people with vertical schuko sticks in their house and one for horizontal. The Horizontal is a updated version so it looks a bit better.

On the picture is my S8, as you can see any Samsung phone would fit. On the Horizontal version it's slightly smaller but still would fit any Samsung phone.

ChipELearning is a robot able to learn movements, which makes every ChipELearning unique ! https://github.com/Ningel85/ChipELearning

Bill of material :
1 x Teensy 3.2
1 x Teensy Shield
1 x Maestro Micro
2 x Servomotor FeedBack Small
4 x Servomotor FeedBack Medium
1 x Accelerometer LSM303D
1 x IR sensor TSOP38238
1 x Remote control
1 x I2C display 128x32
1 x Regulator step-down 5V/3A
2 x Battery 1S
2 x Battery Charger

  • The Teensy controller has various I/Os : I²C, UART, CAN, Touch, ADC, PWM.
    It has an EEPROM big enough for the robot and is smaller than Arduino Uno and Arduino Mega.
  • The Infrared sensor allows me to control the robot with a remote controller.
  • The display is small but still has a decent resolution to write text and display drawings, logos, etc. Wiring the display is very simple as it uses an I²C bus to communicate.
  • Touch I/Os from the Teensy board allows me to interact with the robot without the use of a push button. On ChipELearning, there is a paper fastener but anything else that conducts electricity is suitable.
  • Servomotors send back their position, which allows the robot to memorize sequences of movements and play them back indefinitely.
  • The accelerometer is used for the "Balance" mode. But it could also detect when it's falling or if it is upside down.
  • The robot is powered by 2 Robotis batteries made of one cell each, connected in series. They could be replaced by any power supply up to 16V.
    A power adapter allows to generate a 5V supply for the Teensy controller and the servos.

Functionalities :

  • Remote Controller :
    ChipELearning can be controlled using a remote controller.
  • Walking/Motions :
    The robot can move forwards, backwards and can rotate. 3 sequences of movements are predefined, and binded to keys 1, 2 and 3.
  • Motion learning :
    Motion learning allows the robot to do anything. Jumping, Skateboarding, etc. This feature makes any robot unique.
  • Balance :
    The robot keeps it's balance on it's foot.

Programme TeensyChipE V1.0 TeensyChipE.ino

=================================================================

ChipELearning est un robot capable d'apprendre des mouvements ce qui rend chaque ChipELearning unique! https://github.com/Ningel85/ChipELearning

Bill of material :
1 x Teensy 3.2
1 x Teensy Shield
1 x Maestro Micro
2 x Servomotor FeedBack Small
4 x Servomotor FeedBack Medium
1 x Accelerometer LSM303D
1 x IR sensor TSOP38238
1 x Remote control
1 x I2C display 128x32
1 x Regulator step-down 5V/3A
2 x Battery 1S
2 x Battery Charger

  • Le contrôleur Teensy possède des entrées sorties très variées, I2C, UART, CAN, Touch, ADC, PWM, possède une EEPROM suffisante pour le robot et est plus petite que les arduino uno et mega.
  • Le capteur Infrarouge me permet de contrôler le robot avec une télécommande
  • L'afficheur est petit mais a une bonne résolution pour écrire beaucoup de texte et afficher des dessins, logos... Le câblage est simple et le module communique en I2C, ce qui est très facile à utiliser
  • Les I/O touch de la carte Teensy me permet d’interagir avec le robot sans bouton poussoir. Sur ChipELearning, il y a une attache parisienne mais on peut y mettre tout type d'objet conducteur.
  • Le feedback des servomoteurs retourne leur information de position. Cette option permet au robot de mémoriser les séquences de mouvement pour les refaire indéfiniment.
  • L'accéléromètre est utilisé pour le mode équilibre. Mais il pourrait aussi savoir si il tombe, si il est à l'envers...
  • Le robot est alimenté par 2 batteries Robotis d'une cellule chacune. Elles sont branchées en série. Un régulateur permet d'abaisser la tension à 5V pour le contrôleur Teensy et les servomoteurs. On peut y connecter une batterie de 16V maximum.

Fonctionnalités:

  • Télécommande
    ChipELearning peut-être contrôlé grâce à une télécommande. Avec les flèches directionnelles, des modes de jeux et d'apprentissage ainsi que 9 mouvements.
  • Déplacement/Mouvement
    Le robot peut se déplacer en avant, en arrière et tourner sur lui même. 3 séquences de mouvements sont pré-enregistrées et associées aux touches 1, 2 et 3.
  • Apprentissage de mouvement
    L'apprentissage des mouvements permet au robot de réaliser n'importe quelle action. Sauter, Faire du skate... Cette fonction rend le robot unique!
  • Équilibre
    Le robot reste en équilibre sur son pied. Exemple d'utilisation de l'accéléromètre

Programme TeensyChipE V1.0 TeensyChipE.ino

author: Carvaperc

description.text:
I made a cheap version of the Chip-E, I made this robot, because I think Chip-E is a really great platform to learn about informatics and robotics, but not everyone can afford Chip-E.
The original Chip-E costs 189.95 $, my version should cost you about 10-15$, it depends on how many of the other parts you already have.

Parts needed:

6x 9g Servo 6,6$
1x Ir-receiver 0,11$
1x Arduino promini 1,26$
Some stripboard 1$

Other parts needed:

an old ir-remote
some rubberbands
3D-Printed parts
some foam rubber
an old usb cable
crimp connectors

My robot is not the best robot out there and it´s not the most beautyful one, but it walks and it smiles.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,3mm

Infill:

20%

You will need: 6x 9g Servo 6,6$
1x Ir-receiver 0,11$
1x Arduino promini 1,26$
Some stripboard 1$ Other parts needed: an old ir-remote
some rubberbands
3D-Printed parts
some foam rubber
an old usb cable
crimp connectors

1.I exchanged the lcd, instead of the display I gave hime eyes
2.I had to mage the body bigger to fit everything in it
3.I added details like rubberband hair and a mouth
4.I changed the feet to give him more stability
5.I also shortened the legs to lower the center of gravity

After you printed all parts you should solder all your parts to your PCB, after that you have to take your old usb cable and connect the Vcc and Gnd wires (red and black wires) to Raw and Gnd on your Arduino.
It´s important to connect the Ir-receiver with cables to glue it to the top plate.

After you connected everything you firstly glue some foam rubber under the feet, than you connect your feet servo with the feet plates with some super glue.

Then you have to stick the hip servos in their mounts and srew them in, than you stick the mouth servos in their mount and use some super glue to fix them.

The last two steps are to take your servo connectors and glue or screw your servo arms on them, than you take your mouth parts and assemble them.

Finally you upload your arduino code (you have to change your infrared codes, I also included a programm to read them out) and connect your hip and feet servos.

I uploaded all files I used in the process of designing this thing, I also included the step files for easy customization and remixing.

include // Das Programm greift an dieser Stelle auf eine „Library“ zurück. Das erleichtert einem viel Arbeit. Denn das Infrarotlicht wird mit einem Code verschlüsselt gesendet. Um diesen Code selber auszulesen und in passende Werte umzuwandeln, wären sehr viele Zeilen Code erforderlich.

int RECV_PIN = 2; // Der Kontakt der am Infrarotsensor die Daten ausgibt, wird mit Pin 11 des Arduinoboards verbunden.

IRrecv irrecv(RECV_PIN); // An dieser Stelle wird ein Objekt definiert, dass den Infrarotsensor an Pin 11 ausliest.

decode_results results; // Dieser Befehl sorgt dafür, dass die Daten, die per Infrarot eingelesen werden unter „results“ abgespeichert werden.

void setup()
{

Serial.begin(9600); //Im Setup wird die Serielle Verbindung gestartet, damit man sich die Empfangenen Daten der Fernbedienung per seriellen Monitor ansehen kann.

pinMode (13, OUTPUT);

irrecv.enableIRIn(); //Dieser Befehl initialisiert den Infrarotempfänger.

}

void loop()

{ //Der loop-Teil fällt durch den Rückgriff auf die „library“ sehr kurz aus.

if (irrecv.decode(&results)) { //Wenn Daten empfangen wurden,

Serial.println(results.value, DEC); //werden sie als Dezimalzahl (DEC) an den Serial-Monitor ausgegeben.

irrecv.resume(); //Der nächste Wert soll vom IR-Empfänger eingelesen werden
}
}

description.text:
The larger Mk2 alien ship, (also known as the eye spear) are less common but more dangerous than the Mk1 ships. They have a strong battery of Meson guns on each flank but at long range the central Meson gun mounts can reach far further. The only problem with the Mk2 seems to be that the top speed is much less than the Mk1, or any comparable Federation ships of a similar size, and this can be used to advantage in combat.
The location of the top gun mount is also a mystery and perhaps used with a long axis pivot to bring more guns to bear.
The ship has no shields, as far as we know, but it does have a self healing living outer shell which can absorb a lot more damage than comparable Federation cruisers.

title: MKS Base And MKS-TFT28 Housing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a housing I designed to fit my MKS Base and MKS-TFT28 along with a mosfet for the heatbed to sit next to my Delta for easy control and wiring.

For the back plate I designed 2 versions. One where the cables just run trough the back plate and one for aviation type connectors.
The Mosfet will be placed on the side.

I used 60mm fans so I made proper holes to fit them on the top and back plate.

To space out the MKS-TFT28 just right I needed to put 2.5mm spacers on one side and 3mm spacers on the other. Check yours to see what works best.

Only parts where I used bolts AND nuts is to secure the MKS-TFT28, the fans and the mosfet. The other pieces are tapped with M4 so it would make assembly a lot easier.

I printed everything with 10% infill and it turned out good so it should be sufficient. Up to you if you want to increase that value to make it stronger. If you put all the pieces right on the build plate you'll need a minimum on supports to print it, depends on how you place the parts.

title: Axel's 3D printed quadcopter (carbon fibre arms)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A new better version of this quadcopter available here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2741818

This quadcopter is designed to be lightweight. It uses 14 mm or 16 mm carbon fibre tubes as motor arms. All other parts of the frame are 3D printed. I printed the parts in PLA, but maybe PETG or ABS is a better choice to make it more crash resistant. The motor cables are routed inside the carbon fibre tubes, making the quad look really clean. The quad uses 6-inch propellers and is slightly larger than a standard race-quad. The total flying weight is 630 grams and it has a flight time of about 7 minutes while cruising around at a comfortable pace. Using a 3 cell 2200mAh battery.

This quadcopter is perfect if you want something to fly around Line Of Sight with and maybe do some flips and tricks. The size and shape of the quad makes it easy to see in the sky, compared to normal race-quads. This quadcopter is also perfect if you want to do some calm FPV flying and want longer flight times than normal race-quads.

This quadcopter is not very crash resistant. If you know you crash a lot, or if you are new to the hobby of multi rotors, I recommend trying my other design first. It is slightly heavier but a lot more durable and easier to repair. Link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2230803

The first prototype version of this quadcopter is the one with red motors and motor mounts in the images. It uses those carbon fibre tubes: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/carbon-fiber-round-tube-330x16x14mm.html

They are 16 mm outer diameter, 14 mm inner diameter and 330 mm long. I bought 2 of those and cut them in half to create four 165 mm long motor arms. The 3D printed parts are made to fit any tube with a 14 mm or 16 mm outer diameter. The motor mounts are firstly glued using CA glue to the carbon fibre tubes, then the tubes are glued to the base plate. The camera mount and rear mounting plate are screwed together using short M3 screws and nuts. The top plate is held in place using four 3D printed spacers. The holes in the spacers are slightly smaller than 3 mm, making it possible to thread M3 screws directly into the plastic. The spaces are available with three different hole sizes. Of course, you can also buy aluminium spacers if you prefer that more.

I have also built a second quadcopter with 14 mm carbon fibre tubes. The one with blue motors in the images.

Tricks video here: https://youtu.be/eP1WFb1E-70

Maiden flight video here: https://youtu.be/HPbkTWLpQ8I

Build video here: https://youtu.be/8wl7gxEV0Ps

More info and more high res images on my website: http://axelsdiy.brinkeby.se/?page_id=1390

Edit 2017-07-11
Added Fixed FPV camera mounts if you don't want to use a servo for camera tilt. Three angles are available, 0, 10 and 20 degrees.

Edit 2017-07-14
I crashed my quadcopter and realised a weak point in the base-plate, now I have updated it to hopefully make it a little stronger.

Edit 2017-07-28
Since this project was very successful, I have updated the design slightly to make the quadcopter more durable. I have also added versions of the motor mounts and base plate that works with 14 mm carbon fibre tubes. Now there is also motor mounts with integrated landing gears available.

Edit 2017-08-15
Edited the description and title slightly and added a few new images. Also added plastic spacers that can be used to prevent metal screws from shorting out something on your flight controller.

description.text:
NOW YOU GET A LARGER WORKING AREA EVEN WITH A SMALLER 3D PRINTER!

The new OCTO+ PCB Workstation is the ultimate tool you need to add to your electronic laboratory to facilitate the connection of your lab-tools to the components of an electronic circuit board under testing. It has a rich set of accessories and a wide range of adapters for the most used test clips and probes. It can be equipped with articulated arms (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279) or with crane arms (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2318886), or even with a mix of both of them. The new crane arms have been specifically designed for this new tool and they are long enough to allow the user to reach every point of the circuit board under testing.

The OCTO+ PCB Workstation can be easly made even with small 3D printers. The large circular base can be assembled joining multiple 3D printed parts available in different sizes. If you have a 3D printer with a minimum printable area of 185x185mm, you can use STL files 01 and 02 in order to print the whole circular base. If you have a smaller 3D printer with a minimum printable area of 100x100mm, you can use STL files 03, 04 and 05. If you want to assemble permanently your OCTO+ PCB Workstation, you can glue the XL base parts together.

The OCTO+ PCB Workstation has a 255% larger working area compared to my previous "PCB Workstation with Articulated Arms (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279) and it can fit circuit boards up to 195x195mm or even more (see project pictures).

The circular base can be printed in 2 colors as shown in the project pictures changing the filament at 69% of the printing process (to be verified in your slicing software).

If you don't own a 3D printer or quickly want to get a fully functional OCTO+ PCB Workstation with a large set of printed parts and accessories, it is now available a ready-to-use high quality kit!

OCTO+ PCB WORKSTATION KIT: € 129.90 Euro + shipping

The kit includes the following parts:

1 Circular Base XL
4 PCB Holders (M5 Hex Bolts and Wing Nuts included)
8 Crane Arms for Needle Probes (M4 Hex Bolts and Wing Nuts included) NEW ADDITION!
8 Needles 40x0,80mm (presoldered to cables) NEW ADDITION!
8 Articulated Arms equipped with "Mini Test Clip Hook Grabbers" and proper Adapters

print_settings.Notes:: All parts printed with PETG.

description.text:
Before you start making such a major modification to your Vertex printer please be aware about

Cons:

  • Properly assembled and tuned K8400 can produce rather good printouts and it is unlikely that this upgrade will further improve print quality
  • VertexEvo works in CoreXY printing mode that requires firmware upgrade to the latest Marlin version 1.1.5. As the result you will loose K8400-specific menu items like filament loading/unloading, LED light control, etc. Entire menu structure will be different and it may take you some time to get used to it.
  • Front and side panels of K8400 are not strong enough to hold the amount of load produced in CoreXY mode. As the result the panels wobble and this in some cases may slightly degrade print quality. To address this you will need to attach 25mm x 3mm aluminium bars along the top of front and side panels.
  • You may need to adjust (lower) the speed and acceleration to retain original quality, i.e. overall printing time will increase. At certain speeds side panels start to resonate, which causes additional noise.
  • This mod requires soldering. You will need to relocate X-stop sensor from back panel to the print-head, extend and re-route X-stop wires.
  • You will need to drill a hole in aluminium plate supporting the print-bed to move it forward and down as described here.

and Pros:

  • Printer has much simpler mechanics, only linear bearings and is easier to tune and maintain.
  • There are only 2 belts instead of 6 in the original design.
  • The carriage outer shape is very simple, which makes it easy to change the print-head. You can even design and attach your own print-head, for example single e3D with proximity sensor, etc.
  • When using dual e3D, there is no need to cut heat sinks as in my other designs published here and here.
  • Dual e3D mount can be tilted along Y-axis that makes it very easy to level nozzles.
  • Overall print volume increases from the original 6840 cm³ to over 7414 cm³.
  • This design is completely revertible, i.e. you can always roll back to the old configuration.

Other considerations:

  • STL files posted here were designed for 0.35mm nozzles (wall thickness 0.7, 1.05 and 1.4mm). They were printed with e3D hotend on K8400 that has all my mods posted earlier on Thingiverse. Unfortunately I have no way of testing how well the things posted here will print with the original hotend from Velleman.
  • You will need to use the latest Arduino version to compile and install the latest firmware.
  • Having polyurethane GT2 belts is the must.
  • Having 2 Carbon-fiber 8mm rods for X-axis is highly recommended. Each weights about 14 grams versus 200 grams of steel equivalent.
  • The print volume with dual e3D print-head and MK3 heated bed is X=182mm, Y=210mm and Z=194mm.

Bill of Materials

  • Left Motor and rear-left Y-rod mount
    4 x M3 x 8mm screws for motor mount
    2 x M3 x 12mm screws for Y-rod
    4 x M5 x 16mm socket-cup screws
    4 x M5 self locking nuts
    1 x GT20 pulley with 5mm bore

  • Right Motor and rear-right Y-rod mount
    4 x M3 x 8mm screws for motor mount
    1 x M3 x 12mm screw for Y-rod
    4 x M5 x 16mm socket-cup screws
    4 x M5 self locking nuts
    1 x GT20 pulley with 5mm bore

  • Left Front Corner with front-left Y-rod mount
    1 x M5 x 50mm socket-cup screw
    5 x M5 x 16mm socket-cup screws
    6 x M5 self locking nuts
    2 x GT2 idler pulleys with teeth and 5mm bore
    2 x M3 x 12mm screws for Y-rod

  • Right Front Corner with front-right Y-rod mount
    1 x M5 x 50mm socket-cup screw
    5 x M5 x 16mm socket-cup screws
    6 x M5 self locking nuts
    2 x GT2 idler pulleys with teeth and 5mm bore
    2 x M3 x 12mm screws for Y-rod

  • Left XY Clamp
    2 x M3 x 16mm screws for Y-rods
    6 x M3 x 12mm screws for X-rods
    2 x M5 x 25mm socket head button screws
    1 x GT2 idler pulley with teeth and 5mm bore
    1 x GT2 idler toothless pulley with 5mm bore
    1 x 8mm tube bearing

  • Right XY Clamp
    2 x M3 x 16mm screws for Y-rods
    6 x M3 x 12mm screws for X-rods
    2 x M5 x 25mm socket head button screws
    1 x GT2 idler pulley with teeth and 5mm bore
    1 x GT2 idler toothless pulley with 5mm bore
    1 x 8mm tube bearing

  • Rods
    2 x 8mm x 320mm steel rods for Y-axis
    2 x 8mm x 320mm carbon-fiber rods for X-axis

  • Print head
    4 x 8mm IGLIDUR linear bearings
    2 x e3d v6 original hotends (clones will not fit)
    5 x M4 x 20mm socket cup screws for dual e3d holder and filament fan
    8 x M3 x 15mm screws for dual e3d fan mount and for carriage corners
    5 x M3 x 12mm screws mounting dual e3d holder and pcb with cable holder
    2 x M3 washers (optional but recommended)
    14 x M3 self locking nuts
    9 x M3 x 8mm screws for X-stop sensor, filament fan mount, pcb mount
    4 x M3 x 30mm socket cup screws for belt ends
    1 x filament fan

  • Belts
    2 x 1.5 meters of polyurethane belt with steel enforcement

  • Other
    1 paper clip to hold belt ends

All bearings, filament fan and many screws and nuts can be reused from the original printer.

Printer:

VERTEX K8400 with E3D print-heads

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% and 100%

Notes:

All parts printed with PETG.

I recently learned about HyperCube 3D printer https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2254103 and really like it's simple design with just 2 belts and no rotating rods along X and Y axis. I spent last weekend working on initial design and was able to fit HyperCube-like XY mechanics into Vertex body. Preliminary calculation shows that the change may even slightly increase the printing area from X=210mm, Y=193mm to X=202mm, Y=215mm. These numbers are for dual E3D print head and for the design that does not require drilling extra holes in printer's side panels, i.e. is completely revertible. Will keep posting updates here.

Please share your thoughts in comments area - what in your opinion are the cons and the pros of such change.

UPDATE: 17-Jul-2017
Just published motor mounts and front corner pieces. This is still work in progress, so there is slight chance that they will change. Left and right front corners are identical. Just mirror it before slicing. Finalizing Y-carriages design.

UPDATE: 20-Jul-2017
Published Y-carriages. Left and right - both are identical. Print with everywhere support. Removing support will take some time - just be patient. Each Y-cartridge houses 2 Ingus linear bearings. I am reusing as many parts of the original printer as possible.

UPDATE: 29-Jul-2017
Finally got some action. Print head moves to the home position, which is now in far left corner. Discovered error in firmware. Looks like Vertex specific Marlin was never tested with CoreXY and positioning to X-home works only if Y is not in home position. Will need to fix the code. There will be few improvements to the parts that I've published. So far I was able to get print volume 203mm x 203mm x 203mm. With dual E3d print-head X will be about 180mm. Used carbon fiber rods, but it took hours of sanding to make them fit into linear bearings. Purchased PU GT2 belt; should be delivered in a couple of days.

UPDATE: 31-Jul-2017
Received and installed polyurethane belts. What a difference!! My Vertex in now printing in CoreXY configuration, but there are still over a dozen issues to be addressed, which will take about a week.

UPDATE: 5-Aug-2017
I am at the point when Vertex Evo is finally printing, which is a good news. The bad news, however, is that I don't like how it all came together. I opted for placing X-rods next to each other horizontally to gain space along Z axis. Unfortunately this caused carriage to become very bulky. It is 120mm x 50mm x 84mm (see the image). This limits print space along Y. To regain the space the bed/glass needs to be shifted all the way to the rear panel of the printer and both extruder motors have to be moved out. I decided to abandon this design and reorient X-rods to be one above another like in the original HyperCube. I am already half way working at this new version. Old STLs have been removed from this post and 2 new were uploaded. Please do not start printing until the new design is finalized.

UPDATE: 8-Sep-2017
This project was on hold for about a month due to personal emergency. Few days ago I resumed working on it. New revision with X-rods one above another came together much nicer than my original design. I already have it working and now doing final design changes to maximize print space and simplify assembly and maintenance. There is still an issue with the latest Marlin code. It is related to homing the print-head in CoreXY mode. Y-stop sensor reading is ignored if print-head reaches it before reaching X-stop. The workaround is to power off the printer and move print-head manually in a position where the distance to X-stop sensor is less than the distance to Y-stop. The latest Marlin code also has couple of other "inconveniences"

  • Menu structure differs from the firmware version that came with the printer
  • There is no menu item for loading filaments
  • There is no menu item for controlling LED lights (K8403 add-on)

I will look into this after completing hardware build.

Stay tuned, more updates are coming soon.

UPDATE: 12-Sep-2017
I just published the images and STL files. The printer is working in CoreXY mode. Homeing issue in Marlin still needs to be fixed. Few more pieces need to be printed and/or reprinted. Once all is done I will post remaining STLs and the BOM.

UPDATE: 19-Sep-2017
Make sure to download updated pcb_holder file that I uploaded today. The old design cost me over $100 (dead mainboard) because the screw was touching printed board and shortened heater 1. :(

UPDATE: 27-Sep-2017
Quick update and sorry, no good news. Looks like shortened heater 1 circuit that "fried" the mainboard also damaged display unit. Velleman does not sell display and SD card reader boards. If anyone knows where to get them please send me the link via Comments. I contacted Velleman Support and they suggested to send them all 3 boards for testing. Boards have been delivered last Friday. Waiting for their testing results.
Until this is resolved the project will be on hold.

UPDATE: 8-Oct-2017
Velleman Support has been evaluating/testing my driver daughter boards, display module and SD card reader for over 3 weeks. I decided to move forward without waiting to get these parts back. I purchased silent driver boards TMC2100 and installed them. It took me quite some time to tweak Marlin configuration file and set up correct acceleration and motor current, but I'm finally at the point when I can print again in CoreXY mode. Many thanks to jimconner for sharing his experience with TMC2100-s https://www.thingiverse.com/make:375967 .
I am printing the final revision of all the things right now and hoping to complete this project within the next 7-10 days. I will then share the final versions of STL files. From what I've published only motor mounts and front corner STL-s will remain unchanged.

UPDATE: 29-Oct-2017
I just uploaded all the latest thing files. The description and BOM are coming soon.

UPDATE: 1-Nov-2017
Looking into the option of loosing 10mm by Z-axis and bringing back top panel. This should restore stiffness of the side panels, which is crucial for CoreXY mode.

UPDATE: 4-Nov-2017
It appears that there is no way of bringing back the top panel without drilling new holes in side panels for motor mounts. I will look into other ways to improve side panel stiffness. The good news is - while looking into this option I came up with new XY_clamp design, which is much simpler and easier to print. Will test it today and publish if it works well. Y_clamps won't be necessary. Xclamps, and X and Y_stop_visor shapes will change.

UPDATE: 7-Nov-2017
Uploaded VertexEvo Marlin Firmware with configuration files for dual e3d and heated bed.

UPDATE: 30-Nov-2017
Uploaded redesigned XY-clamps, X- and Y- visors, cable holder (goes above right extruder motor), and 4 wide caps that should be used with 25mm x 3mm reinforcement aluminium bars along the top of front and side panels. Also uploaded rev.2 of fan mount with duct. It contains 2 pieces and is easier to print.

UPDATE: 1-Dec-2017
Uploaded the photos of my printer after this upgrade. This project can now be considered as completed. The only thing I might change in future - replace the original PCB from K8400 that is mounted on print-head with custom one that will be "sandwiched" between the back of the carriage and filament fan mount.

UPDATE: 10-Jan-2018
Uploaded Repetier Host printer configuration screenshots.

UPDATE: 6-Mar-2018
Uploaded revision 2 of motor mounts. Added holes at the back that allow to slide out Y-axis rods without removing corner caps and clamps. This makes it much easier to remove printhead, if needed. Two 9mm holes will need to be drilled in the back panel aligned with the holes in motor mounts.

Considering the amount of changes I was doing to my printer at that time, I decided to take out this extra "variable" and use the original drivers, which work very well. Eventually I may give TMC2100 another try, but at the moment I still have lots of things to do to finalize VertexEvo.

comments.text: Hi Logmett, I just finished "Add 10 mm" and "Adding MK3 Heatbed". After making and update my K8400, it's nice. Thanks your things and yours updates. For your evolution, I prefer two heads E3Dv6 on the front towards the door of the machine for a better access. On my machine, I took out engines to extrude so that the entry of the filament is in the axis of the middle of the width of the spool. It is possible as well as to put 2 heads between axes of X for the stability, but attention in the ventilation. We can also increase the diameter of axes Y. I hope that I was able to bring ideas. comments.author: ZenImp56

comments.text: Forgot to mention - there is an option to turn things around, place XY motors at the top-front corners like in HyperCube and then print head will be facing front of the printer. The downside is - you will need to significantly extend the length of 8-11 wires.
comments.author: ZenImp56

comments.text:
Hi Philippe,
Thanks for suggestions. Placing E3Ds in front and in between the rods were among few options I've looked at. Unfortunately in both cases we significantly loose space along Y. When print head faces back it can go all the way in between XY motors. I yet have to design the carriage, but looks like it will be symmetrical. So we should have options of mounting print heads from either front or back.
I also tried to place two X rods one on top of another, but than we loose along Z. Unfortunately having walls of fixed length and height adds lots on constrains to the design comparing to use of 30x30 extrusion based open cube.
comments.author: ZenImp56

comments.text: hahaha I think the same about this printer. Still some ideas, to make it better, carbon rods, pulleys close to walls, X/Y motors outside case with direct couple instead belts, extruder at top to shorter PTFE tubes and more. but without hope...
comments.author: rafaljot

comments.text:
You're right - I've thought about all these except moving extruders up. That sounds like a good suggestion. The only my concern is - having all motors close to the top of the printer may increase vibration and degrade print quality, but you'll never know until you try :).
... and don't loose the hope - we can do it ;)
comments.author: rafaljot

comments.text:
I reduced much vibration using tmc2208 on XY and lv8729 for extruders.

First printing but it seems as good move.

print_settings.Notes:: The triangular truss may cause some drooping strings to happen (depending on parameters) but these should be mostly cosmetic.

description.text:
This is a general purpose truss structure OpenSCAD library which can be used to render structures familiar to everyone from construction tower cranes. When printed, these are very stiff and strong when considering their light weight.

There are two basic structures: a box truss with pyramidal struts reinforcing each box section (number of sections is parametric), and a triangular truss, meant to be a horizontal component. Optional modules offer bolting points to attach several box trusses together to overcome print volume limitations. Triangular truss allows creating a structure which is stronger at one end, weaker at other end, and scaled dimensions and thicknesses in between.

Examples STL:s are included for the basic building blocks. The .scad source file in the zip file documents the various parameters for the primary modules.

Notes:

The triangular truss may cause some drooping strings to happen (depending on parameters) but these should be mostly cosmetic.

description.text:
Marlin Bug https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/issues/7269

1) When printing attached 170 mm x 170 mm frame,
printer makes first X and Y moves (see picture),
and after reaching upper right frame corner,
it starts lowering plate, moving positive Z,
until it crashes at the Z limit

2) When printing similar frame with 130 mm x 130 mm size
this problem does not happen

3) Firmware: https://github.com/random-builder/Marlin/tree/wanhao-d6-probe
changes are only in Configuration.h and Configuration_adv.h

4) Printer: https://www.monoprice.com/product?p_id=15710
is an Ultimaker 2 clone, and prints OK any objects
smaller then 130 mm x 130 mm in XY size

I needed some small feet for a trophy I am making for a discgolf tournament. The trophy itself was made primarily from waste materials and other recycled parts and thus the feet also should be..

The first revision was made in OpenSCAD for last years trophy and a friend printed them in NinjaFlex for me. Came out nice, but he asked for a parametric version... which turned out to be a little tricky in OpenSCAD (the math.. it baffles me), so since I just started using Fusion 360 and had a pretty good idea how to do it.. well.. here it is :)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

The included STL-file is for a foot that is 20mm wide at the widest point and a total or 12mm tall with a 2mm hole for a screw in the middle.

If you need other dimensions you can open the included Fusion project and change parameters to suit your need. The important parameters are 'totalheight' and 'topdia' which controls the total height of the foot and the diameter at the widest point.
It might be possible to change the chamfer for the screw hole (flat head screws don't need it). If requested, I can add that parameter.

Print settings depend on the printer and the material used.
If I would print this in PLA, and the feet didn't need to support much weight, I would probably just go with 0.8mm walls, 0.6mm top/bottom and 10-20% infill @ 0.2mm layer height.

print_settings.Notes:: You might need to print this multiple times to get it right.

title: XY Size Compensation (Test/Calculator)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Print this to estimate/verify which XY Size Compensation option to set for your printer.

The model consists of two pins (1mm and 2mm) and two measures (even and odd).

The even (bottom in the picture) measure has gaps of sizes:
1.0, 1.2, 1.4, 1.6, 1.8, 2.0, 2.2, 2.4, 2.6, 2.8
The uneven (top in the picture) measure has gaps of sizes:
1.1, 1.3, 1.5, 1.7, 1.9, 2.1, 2.3, 2.5, 2.7

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

any

Infill:

any

Notes:

You might need to print this multiple times to get it right.

Calibration

After you have printed the parts, check into which slot the 1mm and 2mm pins fit.

Example:

2mm fits into the 2.2 mm slot:

  • use a value of -0.05mm for XY Size Compensation (Slic3r)
  • calculation: (2.2-2.0)/4=-0.05 (division by 4, as both the pin and the measure will be influenced on both sides)

After finding the correct values, the measures should fit together as shown in the gallery picture.

title: GoPro Hero Session Mount for Ultimaker

description.text: Did you ever want to record a time-lapse with your GoPro Hero Session when 3d-printing something on your Ultimaker? You were probably not really happy with the standard camera mount and the double-sided tape. This simple camera mount has a hook and it is put up the frame of the Ultimaker. Two angles are freely adjustable and are tightened with a screw. The only thing you need is a M5 nut. I've 3d-printed my mount with anthracite PETG.

description.text: Simple bracket for cable management. I used it for cables coming off my router which is mounted to the ceiling.

You like Munchkin as much as I do? Are you tired of calculating your Item level multiple times per round? Or do you just want your fellow gamers to go green with envy every time they see your lead? Then this state-of-the-art level counter is made for you!

It comes with fancy spinable number discs making it possible to track your player level from 0-9 and your item level from 0-99! Simply add the gain of your shiny new helmet or blood-splattered dagger once per round and you're always up-to-date!

How To

  1. Print all the parts.
  2. Use 3x M4x10mm Screws and 3x M4 nuts to screw everything together (M3 might work as well). Tighten the screw until you're satisfied with how easy or hard the discs turn.
  3. Color it if you like! Please add photos of your MAKE if you do so!
  4. Kill your foes & steal their items for maximum profit!

Disclaimer

I don't own Munchkin, and therefore deleted the Munchkin logo you can see on my MAKE to upload the level counter. Sorry for that! The font is called Quasimodo, so you may search for it and add it yourself via OpenScad if you want to (Write it, make it a picture, extrude this picture & add it to the top disc).
Depending on your printer's accuracy you might need to sand the numbers and words a bit, but it wasn't necessary for me.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

No

No

20%

comments.author: leviray01

comments.text:
I'm curious as to what this "Item level" is.
I've only tried the game once, and wanted to find a counter for next time, to use instead of coins as level-counters.
comments.author: Gertsen

comments.text:
Let's say you have a +3 weapon, +1 helmet, +2 boots and +2 armor, you'd have item level 8.
If your character is level 5, you'd then have a combat strength of 5+8=13, so you can defeat a level 12 monster without help.
It's just a convenient way to remember the combined levels your items add to your character, without having to calculate it each time or writing it up.
In my opinion it's a more convenient way to show your strength off by using a counter instead of multiple cards, which can be quite many later on. This way you and others can see it in one glimpse, and the game is more about the player interaction instead of counting numbers on cards.
I hope you like it! Have fun playing the game :-)
comments.author: Gertsen

comments.text:
I see - we did use item levels after all then.
And yes, this will make it much clearer how powerful each player is :-)

description.text: This is an unbalanced vase (weighted on the left side) to hold small flowers.

I drew this vase by hand on a sheet of paper, then placed a few dots at critical points on curves (see image). I measured and marked the coordinates of each dot in mm (lower left corner was origin). Using 123d software and the "spline" draw tool, I recreated the curves on a 100mm by 125mm by 36mm "box." This was printed on a MakerBot Replicator, then I added quarters in the bottom opening to weight the vase so that it would stand. For more instructions on how to use 123d software for this project, go to: http://www.instructables.com/id/Unbalanced-Vase/ The file, "vase deep hole.stl" holds 16 quarters and will allow larger flowers on the right side.

Adapted some good idea's from others .. thanks guys for sharing!

Due to lack of space around the Talisman table, I needed something to keep charactercards, gold fate and cones together in one tight spot.

Now, this is a cocktail of two things from thingiverse.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1939478 (Special thanks to TalisRob/Talismods !)

  • used as base
  • adapted the back wall to fit the fate-token-holders
  • Placed multi fate-token holder on wall
  • made hole for easy character card removal (for when you die i.e.)
  • added talisman logo engraved in floor

AND

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2341075

  • used chest from model
  • cleaned chest mesh
  • used Fate-token-holder from model
  • adapted token holder and multiplied
  • used cones from model

Chest keeps up to 12 gold coins.
I also added my own made, talisman logo to the bottom of the tray.

-Usage-
To stack the larger cones, leave a small cone underneath the first big one (stability is a choice)

-PrintStuff-
No supports needed.
Tested print on Prusa MKII.

I can only say how gratefull I am that people share stuff so others can change it. So if you're keen to that principle, don't go making money on what people share for free !

-enjoy-

comments.text: Love it, any chance of making the cone turrets any bigger? I keep losing count when I put a little cone under the first big one and it still doesn't quite balance right, so I end up knocking them over anyway.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1A7f90xUuIK

Based on the Toothed rack and gear module 1.5 by denmx, I created the Pull-O-Copter!
A toy that lauches a 100mm (or experimental 150mm) diameter rotor up in the air with one sharp pull!
Perfect for kids and everyone that doesn't hate fun.
Can be used outdoors and indoors.

If you have problems with the files try using the _fix files provided by HAMMER_T(https://www.thingiverse.com/HAMMER_T) for better results

Thanks to HAMMER_T for providing the fixed files!

Pull-O-Copter in action (tiny video):
https://youtu.be/WDU0ompqszc

You'll need 2 m3 screws, length: 10-13mm

Update1:
The rotor now comes in 2 sizes, 100mm and 150mm (150mm doesn't provide much lift yet, will update soon).
Enjoy!

Update2:
Modified the 150mm rotor file for better performance

Update3:
Added fixed files.

Printer:

modded Zonestar P802m

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Nozzle: 0.4mm
Supports required for grip, gear and rotor parts.
Gear printed with 60% infill.
Rotor printed with 15% infill.

After printing make sure to get off the rotors supports cleanly for better aerodynamics.

If the key and the main part dont perfectly work at first just grind them a little by inserting the key multiple times and/or use lubrication.

title: Ogo Fish
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Although this little fish likes to dress itself up with spikes to look more formidable, you can mix and match with the different pieces from the Ogosport page. You could add wings,  flames, swords, or whatever else you want!  
The OGOBILD attachments are interchangeable, safe, and functional toys you can use to create anything you can imagine. Now you can download, modify, and print out your own custom pieces.

The body is split into 4 sections so it could fit on the build plate and be easier to print. You'll need to print each of the fish parts once, 2 eyes, 18 socket to socket connectors, 2 tentacles, and 16 spikes. You could attach any of the other things on the ogosport page to the fish.

title: Qidi X-One panel brackets and handles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I used these parts to create an enclosure for my Qidi X-One. This allows me to print great with ABS. The brackets are glued to acrylic panels. You'll need to test fit each part using hot glue first. This allows you to verify placement before using CA glue (super glue) as hot glue will pull away from the pieces pretty easily. The top brackets should have a little play in them so you can left the panel slightly before pulling away the bottom edge. This is how I lock in my panels during printing. The remaining brackets were used to create the curved acrylic. Heat the acrylic with a heat gun and get it into the approximate shape. Then, use the brackets to lock in the shape. I printed all brackets in PETG for strength and durability.

Printer:

Qidi X-One

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15% or higher, for added strength

Notes:

Some parts will need supports. You may be able to rotate some parts on your bed so they will bridge and not need supports.
Created with Autodesk 123D Design

description.text: My son recently got into D&D and was setting up a One Shot as the Dungeon Master. He wanted a particular monster to fight and after a brief search found MagicEngineer's Beholder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1353092 . The Death Tyrant (from what I'm told...) is a nasty version of the beholder that arises after it dies - so it's just a skull. Apparently it's really pissed off for having died and is very strong and vicious....

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

I brought the original into Autodesk 123D and removed the eye stalks and large eye and just left sockets by removing spherical shapes from the model. I couldn't get the base to print well, so redesigned it to take a piece of bamboo skewer to hold the model above the base.

title: Ventolin Inhaler Cover (Evohaler)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a cap to go over the top of my inhaler. I always carry my ventolin in my pocket incase I have an attack and have found that I often set it off slightly in my pocket so the first puff does not do anything. It can also get bits of pocket fluff \ dirt inside it. So this is a cap I designed to slide over the top to stop it going off in my pocket.

If you don't have a ventolin evohaler it is probably not going to fit. But I have included a STEP file which most CAD programs will import so you can remix away.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

author: jmloureiro77

title: Cub3bot - Print in place, cuboid robot!

description.text:
This is a print in place cuboid robot! It has moving legs and arms that fold up to give it different 'poses'. It also has relatively high tolerance (gaps between joints) so you can print it at down to 45% original size, and as big as your printer can go. The model is designed so it is easy to print, won't cause problems when printing, and won't needs supports, however these are optional (there are over hangs on the back and the face, and although it is pretty well supported, you may want to use supports).

It was designed on fusion 360 which you can find here: https://www.autodesk.com/products/fusion-360/overview

Like my other designs it is print in place, doesn't need supports and isn't from anything, but looks quite cool as a toy or just an ornament.

Thanks for printing and I hope you enjoy :)

Instructions:

Print at a relatively normal/high print speed (50-70 mm per second) for the best results. It has an over hang on the back of the model, but like I said earlier your printer should cope fine with it, unless printing at lower speeds. If you are printing at lower speeds, and you can't speed it up, just file or sand bits of plastic hanging down once printed. Once printed, if you are having an issue where it's not standing up because it's front-heavy, put the infill percentage up. If you do decide to print it smaller, and it doesn't work, you have probably gone too small for your printer to cope with, as 45% the original size is the very minimum a desktop printer can probably go. Also if can not reach the legs through the back, push them up and they should become loose. The arms have four small support structures between the upper arm and the lower, just between the joint. You can either apply a bit more force to the joint, or get a craft knife and cut it free, but either way should work. (The legs also should slot into a hole when standing up, but only if they're pointing straight down.)

If you wish to print with metal filament, I highly suggest using the reinforced model instead of the regular, but if you want to print it smaller with normal PLA or ABS, use the normal model

comments.text: Whats the difference between the reinforced and not?
comments.author: Neat

comments.text: The middle part of the arm joint is slightly thinner, and the outside is thicker, so if when you print with exotic filaments, it is less likely to snap.
comments.author: Neat

comments.text: Oh okay, Thank you! I will be printing one soon I will be sure to add a picture. :)

description.text:
Well if you Creality CR-10 sitting around with your DJI Spark what can you print? Well how about a landing and hover pad with a level? So this pad is 11 inchs around and has surface indentations on it to allow the down facing camera something to lock on and I would suggest printing in either orange or blue to again provide an extra level of contrast to the ground cover.

The bubble levels an be found here: http://amzn.to/2u16JAH and by the way they are very hand and seem to end up in many of my projects! Also it just attaches with a little epoxy or glue...

description.text:
Adapter for turning the vise screw to quickly open the jaw on a milling vise.
really nice when changing jaws!
It's designed to press an M6 bolt in for the axle.

Enjoy!
Let me know if you use it and love it.
SpaceClaim

Warning the part and instructions are not done yet!
Image is of the "Mount 2014-02-06" version. My MendelMax kit came with a y-carriage mounting system where the LM8UU holders where sandwiched between two pieces of particle board. The wood was under pressure and would change flexibility with temperature.
This resulted in a print bed that had to be readjusted before printing anything and again after a few hours of use. This design is my attempt to make a low height Y-Carriage mount for LM8UU bearings using the following rod holders (10mm spacing) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24510 The goals of this design are
  • slim design for 4mm particle board or 4mm Dibond
  • use my LM8UU mount for PLA. This mount is printed on its side to increase part strength
  • use screws that are common in German hardware stores (M3 flat head)
  • solid print base that will stay level
    • Please see "Instructions" for a list of required parts and how to assemble a complete unit.
    Ohh and print this one hot to fuse the layers! I use PLA at 205C with a fan (60-80mm/s). I will not grant Thingiverse an unconditional license to my source files so please go here for the Solidworks part file https://github.com/KaiserSoft/3D-Printing

Print this one hotter to fuse the layers. This will make the part tougher and less flexible, which should improve the resolution of your printer.
I print with PLA at 205C using a fan, 0,3mm layer height, at least 0.6 infill (Slic3r) and 50-80mm/s print speed. You need to purchase these items (still optimizing the part so the screws may change!):
8 x M3 x 12mm flat head screws (mount LM8UU)
8 x M3 nuts
4 x M3 x 40mm any head screws (mount belt holder)
1 x M3 x 25mm any head screws (belt tensioner) 1) Print the following parts
2 x Y-Carriage mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242819
4x LM8UU Clamps http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:244229
1x Belt tensioner (testing it)
1x Belt mount tall (testing it) 2) Mark the center of your thick plate and find a distance for two mounts (triangular parts) to fit on your thick plate. The point of the triangle, the place where you will mount the belt mounts, should point towards the center on both sides. 3) The screw holes on the mounting plate are exactly 100mm apart. Mark two points on your thickplate spaced 50mm from the center line. 4) Align the mount with the markings from step 3. Your mount should be squared now.
Use a pen to mark the rest of the screw holes 5) Drill all 12 holes with a 3mm drill

This is a modified version of the geometry used in DoubleTwistVase2 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412366), but I used only a single twist to eliminate problems with overlapping shells. This part printed in 21 hours using a layer height of 0.200 mm and a print speed of 100 mm/sec.

The issue of overlapping shells is complex, but there are some tricks for dealing with them. See this blog page for more info if you are interested: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/do-the-twist/

description.text:
Hi ya'll. Its summer time which means there are lots of pesky insects. Feel free to use this "Bye Fly Swatter" to alleviate your pain.

Mostly for novelty. But see if you can catch a bug!

Follow on:
https://www.facebook.com/3dprintgeek/
https://www.instagram.com/3dprintgeek/
Not a very loud one, but a pretty fun project. See it in action here: http://youtu.be/V6SdR8xWaw4

I printed all the parts in ABS on a Printrbot. The gears were printed at 100% fill, though I'm not sure that was really necessary, the rest was at 40% Other parts needed:
(2) 1/4 in. hex bolts 2"
(1) 1/4 in. hex bolt 1.5"
(3) 1/4 in. nylock bolts
(2) SR4 bearings (1/4 ID x 5/8 OD x .196) like these: http://www.vxb.com/page/bearings/PROD/SealedBearings/KIt12068
I got all these parts from my local hardware store. Once you have everything, assembly is fairly straight forward. update: I added a duplicate small gear as a separate download at the request of a user.

title: The Last Filament Sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Customizable Filament Sensor

This is hopefully the last filament sensor you'll ever need (for switches anyway). I looked at a bunch, but every one I printed would not fit my switch. They also all seemed to fit different switches... so enter the customizable one. I'm using these, https://www.aliexpress.com/item/MYLB-10-Pcs-AC-125V-1A-SPDT-1NO-1NC-Momentary-Long-Hinge-Lever-Micro-Switch/32745688469.html, though the whole point is it doesn't matter any more. Just measure yours and enter the numbers.

Description

Customizable, so specify the size of your filament and switch and how much space you want for wiring and you're ready.

Measuring the screw holes is probably the most annoying part. Be sure you're calculating the center of the screw hole. To do this, I used my caliper to first measure the screw hole width and depth (mine were not perfect circles), and then I measured the distance from the edge of the hole to the lower left corner of the switch. Lower-left may be arbitrary but if you're using a filament flange and your screws aren't symmetrical it will matter. You must enter both X and Y for both screws (all switches I've seen have 2 screw holes, if you have more or less the thing will have to be updated).

Updated

Added an option to include the space for a square header rather than a hole for the wires. After I put it together I realized it would be a lot more effective to be able to easily attach/detach it and not have something being yanked on. If you don't have the crimpers to do that, the wire hole is still available (though you really should just spend the $20 and get some crimpers).

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.36

Infill:

15

Notes:

I printed in PLA+ and ABS. The design is relatively tolerant, though the cylindrical filament flanges may get a little messy. You could add supports if you care a lot.

description.text:
The Eachine Wizard 220 is very popular and almost indestructible. However with the eventual crash the FPV camera tends to change position. This mount locks the camera into a 25 degree elevated position. The tab on bottom fits into the frame and the top plate sandwiches it into position. The lens cover can still be used.

Update: I ended up gluing the two pieces together on all my quads so I now print them as one piece.

title: My Bowden E3D V6 extruder mount for Anet A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After printing and trying out about a dozen different carriages and mounts for Bowden extruder with a BL touch sensor mount, I decided to design my own. My first ever attempt.
This is a much better design for the BL touch sensor because I have aligned it with the hot end nozzle along the X axis, (15mm to the left) so you don't have to change the Y axis offset in the firmware.
I used this carriage: https://www.thingiverse.com/make:132453. I designed the extruder mount on 123D Design. I have left a gap behind the extruder for the wires to go through in a tidy and secure manner.
Almost forgot to mention... be sure to check your timer belt orientation before printing the carriage. julieng7 and the others have the two bearings on the upper rod and the one on the lower, however the belt orientation of my Anet A8 wants it up side down!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Greetings makers. I feel the need to apologize for hastily uploading my first ever attempt to design and print my own designs without testing first. I have since learned and can now present you with my new corrected and tested version with three or four spools of filament, (PET.G, ABS and Glass Look, all NEEMA 3D). My E3D v6 mount is ABS and the fan duct and base PET.G
I had to glue an extension on the left side of the carriage so that it meets the X axis end stop a centimeter sooner in order to avoid the rear fan crashing into the frame when it homes. T will upload a mod for that ASAP.
I moved the BL Touch sensor to the left side cause it was too close to the heat sink of the extruder.
I used super glue to join the two parts of the fan duct.
I have also added the dx files, feel free to modify.

description.text:
A simple but nice mobile phone stand

It is tall, so that the USB-Plug fits while the phone is on the stand, but with a nicely designed curve so that the proportions are harmonious. The stand is designed so that you can put your phone on an off while the cable is plugged in without disconnecting or hassling with the wire. You even can run the cable trough the big back hole so that you can place the stand anywhere on your desk.

A normal smartphone up to 10mm thick fits perfectly, even a small tablet can be put on it.
